1.title: Our Boarding House
1.author: [No author]
1.series: Feb. 6, 1956) "The Old Gent is Younger than the Major"
notes: Summary: Hannibal Hoople has seen his son's picture in the newspaper, and is coming to visit and help Amos lose weight.

2.title: Our Boarding House
2.author: [No author]
2.series: Nov. 1, 1956) "Did Anybody Leave a Package of Cheese on the Radiator"
notes: Summary: Martha announces to the other boarders that Prescott Pike has checked in.

3.title: Our Boarding House
3.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Pike the television comedian makes a joke about Amos being overweight, and Amos says Pike is the reason TV sets aren't selling.

4.title: Our Boarding House
4.author: [No author]
4.series: Nov. 3, 1956) "Let's Call This Bout a Draw"
notes: Summary: Over the fence, Pike tells Baxter the museums are looking for him as an example of a fossil, and Baxter says Pike's jokes come from the dinosaur egg section.

5.title: Our Boarding House
5.author: [No author]
5.series: Nov. 5, 1956) "Want Us to Hold Some of That For You?"
notes: Summary: Amos sees Pike paying for his room and board, and is impressed by the amount of cash in Pike's wallet.

6.title: Our Boarding House
6.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Major invites Pike to the Owls Club for a poker game.

7.title: Our Boarding House
7.author: [No author]
7.series: Nov. 7, 1956) "He's Lonely and He's Loaded and Wants to Learn Poker"
notes: Summary: The boarders chide Amos for his planning to take advantage of Pike at the Owls Club poker game.

8.title: Our Boarding House
8.author: [No author]
8.series: Nov. 8, 1956) "And Sometimes for Cuff Links and Gold Inlays"
notes: Summary: Pike wants to know how high the stakes are at the Owls Club poker games, and Amos says they play "more for pure sport and fraternal feeling than mere pelf!"

9.title: Our Boarding House
9.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: At the Owls Club, Pike asks somebody else to shuffle the cards because he doesn't know how.

10.title: Our Boarding House
10.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Pike is winning at poker.

11.title: Our Boarding House
11.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos worries that the Owls Club will think he brought them a card shark; Pike says he won $13.65 and if he's a card shark he works cheap.

12.title: Our Boarding House
12.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The boarders tease Amos about Pike's having cleaned out the Owls Club at poker.

13.title: Our Boarding House
13.author: [No author]
13.series: Nov. 14, 1956) "You Can Always Crawl Under the Rug"
notes: Summary: Amos and the boarders complain about their blankets being thin, because the rest of them are at the cleaners. Martha says if they plan to freeze to death tonight they better pay their back rent now.

14.title: Our Boarding House
14.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Major is working out in the basement, and the boarders assume he's working up an appetite for Thanksgiving.

15.title: Our Boarding House
15.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Tony is massaging Amos's scalp vigorously and Amos compares him to Frank Gotch, saying he's not one of his "crew-cut clientele." Meanwhile Tony is arguing about a bet on a horse race.

16.title: Our Boarding House
16.author: [No author]
16.series: Nov. 17, 1956) "Keep It? What Else Can He Do With It?"
notes: Summary: Tony the barber has given Amos a crew cut by mistake, and when Amos promises lawyers Tony says all they'll get is a haircut.

17.title: Our Boarding House
17.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos comes home with a crew cut, saying the barber was distracted by wagering, and Martha wonders how the bristles stand up in "all that lard."

18.title: Our Boarding House
18.author: [No author]
18.series: Nov. 20, 1956) "Maybe He Ought to Go Back to School"
notes: Summary: The crew cut makes Amos feel younger.

19.title: Our Boarding House
19.author: [No author]
19.series: Nov. 21, 1956) "He's Been Surveying It from All Angles"
notes: Summary: The boarders poke fun at the Major's crew cut, and he puts it down to envy.

20.title: Our Boarding House
20.author: [No author]
20.series: Nov. 22, 1956) "Baxter Has Only a Fringe, Like a Surrey"
notes: Summary: Baxter pokes fun at Hoople's crew cut, and Hoople remarks on how Baxter never goes hatless.

21.title: Our Boarding House
21.author: [No author]
21.series: Nov. 23, 1956) "They're Old School, Plastered Hair Models"
notes: Summary: Around the pool table, Amos is teased about his crew cut with suggestions that he looks like a prisoner or a sophomore.

22.title: Our Boarding House
22.author: [No author]
22.series: Nov. 24, 1956) "He Doesn't Mind Being Told He Looks Younger"
notes: Summary: Leander likes Uncle Bulgy's new haircut.

23.title: Our Boarding House
23.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Hoople feels tired and is worried about it; Mack suggests he eats too much and Buster suggests he drinks too much.

24.title: Our Boarding House
24.author: [No author]
24.series: Nov. 27, 1956) "Go Stick Your Head in the Oven"
notes: Summary: The Major reads "Gypsy Gert's Medical Book" in which she uses the example of Samson to connect short hair with lack of vigor, and recommends keeping the head warm.

25.title: Our Boarding House
25.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos is wearing a coonskin cap to promote hair growth. Buster wants to know if he's planning to move to a possum colony, and Mack speculates about Daniel Boone.

26.title: Our Boarding House
26.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos is wearing a turban to generate heat, and Martha suggests another system: household chores.

27.title: Our Boarding House
27.author: [No author]
27.series: Nov. 30, 1956) "The Coonskin Cap Wouldn't Help Either"
notes: Summary Leander has booked Uncle Bulgy for a speech on juvenile delinquency at the PTA, and Amos worries about his crew cut detracting from his dignity.

28.title: Our Boarding House
28.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos's father left a toupee behind, and Amos decides to wear it when he addresses the PTA, to hide his crew cut.

29.title: Our Boarding House
29.author: [No author]
29.series: Dec. 2, 1956) "What If Junior Kicks the Slats Out of His Crib?"
notes: Summary: Major Hoople rehearses his speech about juvenile delinquency, mentioning Henry James, Plutarch, Greek poets, Pasteur, Lincoln and John L. Sullivan.

30.title: Our Boarding House
30.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: On the way to the PTA meeting, Leander worries about the Major's propensity to use words that are too big, and Martha hopes he quits before the audience starts to snore.

31.title: Our Boarding House
31.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Major is sweating and addressing the PTA meeting about juvenile delinquency, while his wig "itches infernally."

32.title: Our Boarding House
32.author: [No author]
32.series: Dec. 6, 1956) "If Only Somebody Would Holler Fire"
notes: Summary: Amos is addressing the PTA about the juvenile problem, and his wig is falling down over his face.

33.title: Our Boarding House
33.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos's wig fell off and he apologizes, but the teacher liked his talk on the juvenile problem, and the principal appreciated getting Mark Antony and slapstick at the same time.

34.title: Our Boarding House
34.author: [No author]
34.series: Dec. 8, 1956) "And It Was a Surprise, Too"
notes: Summary: The nephews enjoyed Uncle Amos's PTA presentation... "like the Gettysburg Address and Bugs Bunny both for free."

35.title: Our Boarding House
35.author: [No author]
35.series: Dec. 10, 1956) "You Forgot to Add Kyuk-Kyuk, Major"
notes: Summary: Pike makes fun of Amos because his wig fell off at the PTA meeting, and Amos invites him to play a monkey at the next meeting. Amos is painting a still life (fruit) and eating the fruit.

36.title: Our Boarding House
36.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Major is fencing with a dress form in the attic, and asks the boarders to fence with him for practice.

37.title: Our Boarding House
37.author: [No author]
37.series: Dec. 12, 1956) "Yes, Women Have Been Smart a Long Time"
notes: Summary: Martha has borrowed money from Amos's pants pocket while he slept, and has to explain why cave women sewed pockets on their men's tiger skins.

38.title: Our Boarding House
38.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Some of Major Hoople's ideas for inventions are under derisive attack: counterfeit money in banks to foil robbers, and rubber picture frames to fit all pictures.

39.title: Our Boarding House
39.author: [No author]
39.series: Dec. 14, 1956) "A Good Night to Go Out to a Movie"
notes: Summary: Ace Brannigan and Sparrow Felch are at the door, having been invited to a fish fry, and it's a surprise for Martha, but she lets them in. Amos isn't home.

40.title: Our Boarding House
40.author: [No author]
40.series: Dec. 15, 1956) "Which is Worse, the Reward or the Busted Spring"
notes: Summary: Buster came home last night and found two of Amos's friends (Sparrow and Ace) in his bed; as a reward for sleeping on the couch Buster is offered breakfast in bed.

41.title: Our Boarding House
41.author: [No author]
41.series: Dec. 17, 1956) "Or Was It a Tool Chest?"
notes: Summary: Hoople and Baxter trade insults over the back fence, about the Owls Club and an egg-beater that Mrs. Baxter got for Christmas once.

42.title: Our Boarding House
42.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos is selling chances on a "huge gaily wrapped box of Yule goodies" for the Owls Club.

43.title: Our Boarding House
43.author: [No author]
43.series: Dec. 19, 1956) "Or a Year's Supply of Bobby Pins"
notes: Summary: Amos is Christmas shopping in the dime store, checking out the propeller beanies. Martha spots him and expects a nutmeg grater in her stocking.

44.title: Our Boarding House
44.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The Major has been Christmas shopping, and Mack wonders if they're getting diamonds. Buster remembers getting fortunetelling cards that correctly predicted appendicitis.

45.title: Our Boarding House
45.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Major Hoople is hanging mistletoe.

46.title: Our Boarding House
46.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Alvin's violin lesson with Prof. Frantz isn't going well, because Uncle Amos spilled mustard on the music.

47.title: Our Boarding House
47.author: [No author]
47.series: Dec. 24, 1956) "The Foreman is in Fine Form"
notes: Summary: The Major supervises the boarders as they trim the Christmas tree, in the midst of a story about a lighthouse on the Bering Sea.

48.title: Our Boarding House
48.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Presents are opened: a necktie, a shirt, gloves and a blouse.

49.title: Our Boarding House
49.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Baxter scoffs to see a 'hippo pushing a little vacuum cleaner at a pile of snow,' but Hoople says it's working.

50.title: Our Boarding House
50.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: At the pool table, Hoople proposes a cultural fiesta for New Year's Eve, instead of the usual monkeyshines.

51.title: Our Boarding House
51.author: [No author]
51.series: Dec. 28, 1956) "Then You Won't Mind This Little Blizzard"
notes: Summary: The Major talks about swimming in Hudson Bay with pneumonia to rescue Eskimo fishermen.

52.title: Our Boarding House
52.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Major Hoople evaluates the past year and can think of no shortcomings; he's ready to greet 1957 with "the bold brave smile of the Three Musketeers."

53.title: Our Boarding House
53.author: [No author]
53.series: Dec. 31, 1956) "A Cigar Maybe and a Little Singing"
notes: Summary: Last year Amos came home New Year's morning on an ironing board, and the year before in a wheelbarrow. The boarders wonder what to expect this year.

54.title: Our Boarding House
54.author: [No author]
54.series: Apr. 12, 1958) "Stand By to Catch the Lifeline, Major"
notes: Summary: The Major is launching a lawn project, but the wind is blowing the grass seed away. Jason figures he'd better rescue him.

55.title: Our Boarding House
55.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Pike tells a joke about a doctor taking blood tests, and asks Petronius the parrot about taking a flyer at a TV career; the Major feels like a backdrop standing on the set holding the parrot.

56.title: Our Boarding House
56.author: Bill Freyse.
56.series: Apr. 15, 1960) "Adding Some Hot Stuff from a Cold Climate"
notes: Summary: Amos complains about his subordination to a parrot on the last show, and Pike says he's booked Sir Guy Wainwright, the Arctic explorer, for the next program. Pike is holding a record, labelled 'Prescott Pike Performs.'

57.title: Our Boarding House
57.author: Bill Freyse.
57.series: Oct. 25, 1960) "Furthermore, It Will Be In Color"
notes: Summary: Uncle Amos has lost his temporary football coaching job, because Pops Slurg is back; Martha says not to tell Amos because the story he'll come back with will be better than TV.

58.title: Our Boarding House
58.author: Bill Freyse.
58.series: Oct. 26, 1960) "He's a Pro, All Right, with Alibis"
notes: Summary: Pops Slurg tells Major Hoople he's no longer needed as high school football coach, and Hoople says that by coincidence he's gotten coaching offers from three professional teams.

59.title: Our Boarding House
59.author: Bill Freyse.
59.series: Oct. 27, 1960) "The Boys are Working, on Him"
notes: Summary: Hoople explains at dinner that he resigned his coaching job because Pops Slurg's livelihood was threatened, and the boarders express disbelief.

60.title: Our Boarding House
60.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Martha wakes Amos at 10:15 with a snap of the window shade, saying "No Work, No Food."

61.title: Our Boarding House
61.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Hoople plays his recorded readings of Shakespeare and Lincoln, and the room gets quiet.

62.title: Our Boarding House
62.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major gets a wire from President Oswald Humm of Low Fidelity Records expressing interest in his record; the boarders suggest they may be needing to frighten bats out of steeples, or wring confessions out of prisoners without leaving thumbprints.

63.title: Our Boarding House
63.author: Bill Freyse.
63.series: Aug. 1, 1961) "Looks Like a Big Day for Everybody"
notes: Summary: Amos is on his way to Low Fidelity Records to sign a contract selling the Hoople Dictation Discs; Twiggs has only been watching an apprentice barber shave a wrestler, so he'll come along.

64.title: Our Boarding House
64.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: President Humm of the record company doesn't dig the Major's culture jazz, but the Hoople Diction Disc is a sleep-producer; it conked out the board of directors.

65.title: Our Boarding House
65.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: They tried the Major's record at the zoo, and a gorilla fell asleep peeling a banana; it's an automatic snoozer and the offer is $100; Amos thinks the idea is libelous but Twiggs shuts him up.

66.title: Our Boarding House
66.author: Bill Freyse.
66.series: Aug. 4, 1961) "The Major has a Large Nest Egg Twiggs Doesn't Know About"
notes: Summary: Amos chides Twiggs for making him, of a line of Shakespearean actors, accept money for his speeches to be used as a sleep-producing record; Twiggs reminds him that Shakespeare himself wrote for money, the best kind of applause.

67.title: Our Boarding House
67.author: Bill Freyse.
67.series: Aug. 5, 1961) "Run Along Boys, and Don't Disturb Genius at Work"
notes: Summary: Now that the Hoople Diction Disc idea has been sold, the boarders expect the Indians to win the next TV western, or has the hearing aid picked up Swahili short-wave again? The Major dismisses them to concentrate on his new practical plans for desalination of sea water.

68.title: Our Boarding House
68.author: Bill Freyse.
68.series: Aug. 7, 1961) "His Curve Ball Worked in the Clutch"
notes: Summary: Twiggs wants to know how Amos explained that his record has been sold as a sleep aid; as a former Oxford debating champion he's been telling people that it's being released in England.

69.heading: Our Boarding House (Aug. 8, 1961).
69.title: "He's a Touch Target from Now On"
69.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Word is around that the Major has money, and his friends ask for loans to avoid the poorhouse, high bridges, and muscling in on the squirrels' peanuts in the park.

70.title: Our Boarding House
70.author: Bill Freyse.
70.series: Jan. 31, 1962) "After One Swing of the Pan They Compromised on $100"
notes: Summary: Amos has $300 and he's going to develop a gold mine; Martha starts panning for her share right away.

71.title: Our Boarding House
71.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major is selling lawn chairs, and the customer says the last peddler sold her spot remover that ate a hole in the rug. She threatens to release her surly dog, and Amos thinks that's a fate better reserved for his brother in law.

72.title: Our Boarding House
72.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The people who saw Amos sleeping in traffic all want to buy lawn chairs.

73.title: Our Boarding House
73.author: Bill Freyse.
73.series: Oct. 1, 1963) "Making the Most of a Lucky Break"
notes: Summary: Selling all those lawn chairs is the biggest surprise since the hula hoop riots, and Amos brags about his salesmanship.

74.title: Our Boarding House
74.author: Bill Freyse.
74.series: Oct. 2, 1963) "He's Not Quite That Bad, Martha"
notes: Summary: The lawn chair business is working, and Amos gives Martha $15. The last time Martha got money from Amos was when she took the blame for his sitting on her father's ukulele.

75.title: Our Boarding House
75.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The boarders discuss how to trick Hoople into entering a cooking contest.

76.title: Our Boarding House
76.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Martha decides to let Amos use the kitchen but not the dining room, and Amos says she'll miss the opportunity to be in the photograph when the press comes to interview the cooking contest winner.

77.title: Our Boarding House
77.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Having won the contest Amos claims some leisure, but Martha notes that his sauce is peeling her varnish and demands that he start washing his pots and pans.

78.title: Our Boarding House
78.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Tapioca either grows on cobs like corn or on bushes in Java.

79.title: Our Boarding House
79.author: Bill Freyse.
79.series: Feb. 20, 1964) "He Just Remembered He Forgot to Mail the Hoople Christmas Cards!"
notes: Summary: Amos left them in the coatroom up in the Owls Club.

80.title: Our Boarding House
80.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: "Every crackpot within pogo-stick distance" is after Amos's winnings; she wants him to let it be known that it was only $100.

81.title: Our Boarding House
81.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major had been hoping to withdraw from his financial misunderstandings, and explain in an interview at the dock when he got back, but there's a reporter in the front room.

82.title: Our Boarding House
82.author: Bill Freyse.
82.series: June 10, 1964) "It's All Up To Gregory Now"
notes: Summary: Amos is in the back yard with a dummy and a crate labelled "Harvard." "Can Do" is arriving, and Gregory is going to demonstrate his training.

83.title: Our Boarding House
83.author: Bill Freyse.
83.series: Aug. 1, 1964) "Get Me Some Pipe and a Faucet!"*
notes: Summary: The juice at the bottom of the silo makes the pigs go around in staggers.

84.title: Our Boarding House
84.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major is hiding and reading in the hayloft to avoid work, except at mealtimes.

85.title: Our Boarding House
85.author: Bill Freyse.
85.series: Aug. 4, 1964) "The Horse is Being Broken for the Second Time"
notes: Summary: The boarders make jokes about Amos being too heavy for the horse he's riding; he compares them to horseflies.

86.title: Our Boarding House
86.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Major Hoople jollies Mrs. Butler, telling her how much Charles DeGaulle would like her pancakes; last night her chicken and dumplings reminded him of his dinner with President Johnson.

87.title: Our Boarding House
87.author: Bill Freyse.
87.series: Apr. 22, 1965) "For Once He'll Skip the Details"
notes: Summary: At the poker game, the Owls want to know how his slippers wager with the boarders came out; he won but he's been so busy with research he tends to forget about minor diversions.

88.title: Our Boarding House
88.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Owls Club's new tin poet produces its first poem.

89.title: Our Boarding House
89.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major is pacing in a cloud of cigar smoke trying to figure out how to get the money Jake owes him; a boarder suggests using some habeas corpus double-talk to scare it out of him.

90.title: Our Boarding House
90.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The boarders want Jake to join their poker game, but Jake is suspicious that Amos is using them somehow to get revenge.

91.title: Our Boarding House
91.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: With a lucky break, Amos has gotten the best of Jake for once, and now the boarders expect to hear about it for a long time.
Key words: Mental judo, yakking.

92.title: Our Boarding House
92.author: Bill Freyse.
92.series: Dec. 11, 1965) "He Remembered Martha's Orders Not to Quit"
notes: Summary: The boss tells Hoople to get in a Santa suit, which for a Shakespearean actor of his stature is unthinkable.

93.title: Our Boarding House
93.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major is bragging about catching jewel thieves, and Buster wishes for a hearing aid with no batteries.

94.title: Our Boarding House
94.author: Bill Freyse.
94.series: Jan. 29, 1966) "Jake is an Authority on Sure Things"
notes: Summary: The boarders are watching wrestling on television, and talking about how quiet it is with the Professor gone. After cleaning up at poker the Professor is headed for Las Vegas, where he's working on the odds of filling an inside straight, but they think Jake Hoople is a match for him.

95.title: Our Boarding House
95.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The boarders complain about the Major's cooking, remembering his hard-boiled applesauce.

96.title: Our Boarding House
96.author: Bill Freyse.
96.series: May 21, 1966) "An Orgy of Litterbugging Unless I Serve Nothing but Gourmet Meals"*
notes: Summary: Twiggs says the roast might interest a fire extinguisher salesman; Amos is caught between Martha's orders and the boarders' threats.

97.title: Our Boarding House
97.author: Bill Freyse.
97.series: Dec. 23, 1966) "Better Stay off the Sofas, Major"
notes: Summary: Major Hoople is put off by the crowd of shoppers at the department store, and considers shopping in the furniture store next door instead.

98.title: Our Boarding House
98.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The boarders tease the Major about maybe building a giant snorkel, or painting every other house black to cause a breeze.

99.title: Our Boarding House
99.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: An authority on dogs asks if Templeton is being entered in the dog show.

100.title: Our Boarding House
100.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Martha wakes Amos at 11:15 by poking him with a fishing rod, calling him a groundhog and telling him to get up and see his shadow before she says it in braille; he has missed the fishing contest.

101.title: Our Boarding House
101.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Pop Hoople has both his sons on their backs seeing stars and birdies, and Buster says it was the best instant peacemaking he's seen since the vigilantes lost their rope.

102.title: Our Boarding House
102.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Neighbor Harvey Baxter is in his yard with his push mower as Amos' father leaves on his motorcycle; Amos is about to launch a story about a special assignment for the governor.

103.title: Our Boarding House
103.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: Hoople puzzles over his missing shish kawienie samples, until he remembers that Templeton was guarding them.

104.title: Our Boarding House
104.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The boarders are playing darts and commenting on the dog they heard about that ate the samples, and the fact that Templeton doesn't look well.

105.title: Our Boarding House
105.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The Major describes the new family, the Burbles. They hear their lawnmower, which sounds like a bowling ball in a cement mixer.

106.title: Our Boarding House
106.author: Bill Freyse.
notes: Summary: The riding lawnmower next door actually sounds worse than Buster's car.

107.title: Our Boarding House
107.author: Branagan & McCormick.
notes: Summary: Templeton will perform after his supper.

108.title: Our Boarding House
108.author: Branagan & McCormick.
notes: Summary: Templeton goes to lie down when the Major commands him to, and two of the boarders are impressed, but Buster objects.

109.title: Our Boarding House
109.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: The boarders are trying to decide how much to bet against Templeton's ability to do tricks, and one of them has another idea.

110.title: Our Boarding House
110.author: Branagan & McCormick.
notes: Summary: The Major is planning to sneak up on the boarders, a shadowed figure lurks behind him, and Templeton is asleep.

111.title: Our Boarding House
111.author: Branagan-McCormick.
notes: Summary: Art Pringle has passed the hazing and been voted in by the other boarders.

112.title: Our Boarding House
112.author: Branagan-McCormick.
notes: Summary: The Major meets up with Clyde Thumbscrough, the salesman who sold the development with all those flooded basements. His name is now Clyde Throckbury, because it's easier to spell.

113.heading: Our Boarding House--Articles About.
113.title: "Boarding House Days and Arabian Nights : the Life and Imaginary Times of Major Hoople"
113.author: by Donald Phelps
notes: Includes 4 p. of reprints from Our Boarding House, by Gene Ahern.

114.heading: Our Boarding House--Articles About.
114.title: "Boarding House Days and Arabian Nights : The Life and Imaginary Times of Major Hoople" p. 243-261 in Reading the Funnies : Essays on Comic Strips, by Donald Phelps
114.author: [No author]

115.heading: Our Boarding House--Articles About.
115.title: "Major Hoople : A Comic Hero in the American Tradition"
115.author: by Terry J
115.appears_in: Scullin. 34 p. in The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 3 (1970).
notes: About Our Boarding House.
Includes a cast of characters.

116.heading: Our Boarding House--Articles About.
116.title: "There Was a Real Hoople"
116.author: by Russ Winterbotham
116.appears_in: 5 p. in The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 3 (1970).
notes: About Our Boarding House.

117.heading: Our Boarding House--Miscellanea.
117.title: "Death of Major Hoople Cartoonist Ends Memorable 30-Year Career."
117.author: [No author]
notes: Newspaper clipping dated March 1969 but without source given, on William 'Bill' Freyse who died March 3, 1969 at age 70.
He drew Our Boarding House from Sept. 5, 1939 to Apr. 20, 1969. The art will be continued by James P. Branagan, and Tom McCormick will continue to write the feature.

118.heading: Our Boarding House--Miscellanea.
118.title: Dictionnaire Encyclopdique de Hros et Auteurs de BD
118.author: Henri Filippini

119.heading: Our Boarding House--Miscellanea.
119.title: 100 Years of American Newspaper Comics : an Illustrated Encyclopedia
119.author: edited by Maurice Horn.

120.heading: Our Boarding House--Miscellanea.
120.title: The World Encyclopedia of Comics
120.author: ed. by Maurice Horn

121.heading: Our Boarding House--Miscellanea.
121.title: "Famed Cartoonist Dies." Associated Press datelined Weston, Conn., for Woodson Cowan, saying he drew "Our Boarding House" from 1931 to 1956. Clipping is dated June 1977, and Cowan died at age 90.

147.heading: "Our Brightest Hope."
147.title: Bone : Rose
147.author: by Jeff Smith ; with illustrations by Charles Vess.

Originally published in the comic book Rose, 2000-2002.

Summary (from SkyRiver): Princess Rose musters up courage to face the dragon that threatens the small towns in the Northern Valley, only to discover the dragon is actually the Lord of the Locusts; and meanwhile, her sister, Princess Briar, embarks on a more sinister quest.

150.author: by Harvey Pekar & Joyce Brabner ; illustrations by Frank Stack

151.heading: Our Cancer Year.
151.title: American Splendor [videorecording]
151.author: HBO Films in association with Fine Line Features presents a Good Machine production, a film by Shari Springer Berman & Robert Pulcini ; produced by Ted Hope ; written and directed by Robert Pulcini & Shari Springer Berman.
notes: 1 videocassette (101 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
VHS.
Originally released as a motion picture in 2003.
Based on the comic book series "American Splendor" by Harvey Pekar and "Our Cancer Year" by Harvey Pekar and Joyce Brabner.

Summary (from OCLC): Pekar is a frustrated file clerk working at the local V.A. Hospital. He is also a comic book fan who befriends the young illustrator Robert Crumb and is soon inspired to create comic books based on his own life. Along his bumpy journey he meets, marries and falls in love with Joyce, an admiring comic book seller.
